Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

- Don't explain yourself. Just apologise.
- Genuinely accept and understand the fact that you made an error. 
- If you don't think you made an error, or aren't sure exactly where you went wrong, ask them as open ended as possible ("So I know better next time, what was my mistake?"). Then LISTEN.
- Keep it simple and brief
- Move on. Get back to doing what you have to do.

- Don't screw it up again.
Missed the 4th. Accept your fate.    Too many appear to think apologizing cleans the slate.   It doesn’t.

1. Say what you think to you did.
1. Say what you think the impact of that was.
1. Ask them if they think you understand the problem.
1. Apologise.
1. Explain how you think you can improve.
1. If appropriate, ask them whether they think that will solve the problem.

Apologising is considerably less effective if the other party doesn't think you understand the harms you have caused. Sometimes they may also be wrong about those harms, you can still apologise but you should be explicit about where you both disagree about impact.

It really is that simple.

>1. Say you’re sorry and what you did

Very good. An apology is unconditional, and it's about what you did, not "what happened". 

Don't do an **If**pology (*I'm sorry* **if** *I hurt you*). Those suck.     
Don't offer condolences (*I'm sorry that you* **got hurt**). That's cowardly.
Sounds like all the YouTube apology videos.

In my culture, and language, we don't apologize. We literally don't have a word or phrase to let others know that we're apologetic. Instead, we have *Toh Tsui*. It translates to *"...begging for punishment."* Like, if I accidentally kill someone and I am truly remorseful, I will say *Toh Tsui.* It means I acknowledge my fault(s), and I accept whatever the punishment is. It's quite awkward because, if I accidentally step on your foot, I have no way of apologizing without seeming melodramatic. I can't say *Toh Tsui* because that's such a small issue. So, instead, maybe I'd say, *"Oops! I stepped on your foot!"*
many famous people's and companies' PR representatives should read this post
"Sorry you feel like I did something wrong" usually does the trick.
This sub is for toddlers now

I feel like step 0 is to first mentally acknowledge that you have done something wrong, and that the purpose of the apology is to express your regret, it isn't some way to passive-aggressively dodge blame. If you don't honestly think you did something wrong, but you have to apologize anyway, you still have to do this step or your apology will come out sounding fake and whatever your reason for apologizing, it won't be enough.

If you don't do this step first, most people's tendency will be to follow the next 3 steps and pepper them with passive-aggressive insinuation that really if you think about it, this is all someone else's fault and I haven't actually done anything wrong.

My culture, at least, has normalized the idea of an apology just being yet another way to prove you haven't done anything wrong. If you don't think you've done anything wrong, don't apologize. If you're apologizing, make it clear you accept responsibility for your own actions.

You can definitely do both, you can say you're sorry for one thing while also saying you don't think you're responsible for something else. In that case, make sure they are two separate statements, and absolutely make sure you aren't conveying the idea of, "the thing someone else did means the thing I did isn't even bad" or else you're still just avoiding responsibility and shouldn't be apologizing.

On a related note. I used to work in live television, so the margin for error was very narrow when people are on television literally now. I trained a guy, I think overall I trained him well, but one of the things I taught him was what he should do when, inevitably, he made a mistake.

Literally his first day solo he made a huge blunder that caused an on-air error. At the commercial he was getting reamed for it. When the manager yelling at him paused for breath, he did exactly what I told him to do. He said, "Sir, I'm sorry. I know what I did, and it will not happen again." No explanation, no excuses (largely for reasons of time, the commercial was going to end soon and we'd be back on air.)

And. That was the end of it. The manager shook his hand, congratulated him on taking responsibility and focusing on what mattered, and went back to the show. He ended up taking another job after a few months but basically the whole scenario made him a hero and he didn't get in much trouble for his mistake.

He didn't try to foist off any blame, he didn't make excuses, he expressed sincere regret and most importantly the responsibility to make sure it doesn't happen again. In the moment, the manager did not need to know the specifics, there was no time for something like that. My trainee was still the only person right there who could have done that job in the 90 seconds they had before the commercial ended, and he convinced them (and was right) that his mistake didn't mean he couldn't do it.
4. Don't fucking do it again!
If you don't know this, inherently, you are fucked.
Also don’t say I’m sorry for things that are not your fault.
3. Ask for forgiveness.

My mom's advice about apologies, and in general

"Don't say you're sorry unless you mean it." and 

"Sorry means you won't do it again." And lastly, 

"Say what you mean, and mean what you say."
Don't start with "I'm sorry."  Start with what you did, then say why it was wrong and that you're sorry.  Step 3 is perfect.
Wow this is so smart
This is a great tip. Can I add: always maintain eye contact:)
Step 4. Actually do things differently in the future
Thank u every time I apologize to my wife she never believes me.
